channel.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
channel.description: if you have a basic ::say command please post, thanks

item.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:10, topic:224327”][quote=Lothy] for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
}[/quote]

[quote=Lothy]for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
}[/quote]
L2Code, don’t use brackets where bracket’s are nott needed.

Also with KO9’s code, i don’t think he did write that… cause as far as i remember, i leeched my code from some other source cause it saved me writing it, and im pretty sure it looks the same as that.[/quote]
Using brackets is a good practice. Omitting them is stupid, and makes it unclear and can sometimes break the scope, causing a bug to occur.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source

item.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:11, topic:224327”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=294698.msg2372047#msg2372047 date=1218264152]

[quote=Lothy] for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
}[/quote]

[quote=Lothy]for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
}[/quote]
L2Code, don’t use brackets where bracket’s are nott needed.

Also with KO9’s code, i don’t think he did write that… cause as far as i remember, i leeched my code from some other source cause it saved me writing it, and im pretty sure it looks the same as that.
[/quote]
Using braces is for the sake of clarity, as is spacing. It boils down to opinion, but using them is often more valid than not using them.

If he ever chooses to add an extra statement under my sendMessage(String) call then there is a far greater chance that a bug will NOT occur.
On the other hand, if he was to add a statement under mine and I didn’t put braces, there’d be a reasonable chance that a bug would find its way into the code (Yes, a lot of people do overlook things like that).

@Yz: I doubt it.[/quote]
Ok Pets

Read full topic

Also with KO9’s code, i don’t think he did write that… cause as far as i remember, i leeched my code from some other source cause it saved me writing it, and im pretty sure it looks the same as that.[/quote]
Using braces is for the sake of clarity, as is spacing. It boils down to opinion, but using them is often more valid than not using them.

If he ever chooses to add an extra statement under my sendMessage(String) call then there is a far greater chance that a bug will NOT occur.
On the other hand, if he was to add a statement under mine and I didn’t put braces, there’d be a reasonable chance that a bug would find its way into the code (Yes, a lot of people do overlook things like that).

@Yz: I doubt it.

item.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) { p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message); }
for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) { p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message); }
L2Code, don't use brackets where bracket's are nott needed. :D

Also with KO9’s code, i don’t think he did write that… cause as far as i remember, i leeched my code from some other source cause it saved me writing it, and im pretty sure it looks the same as that.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source

item.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:8, topic:224327”][quote author=KO9 link=topic=294698.msg2369559#msg2369559 date=1218151757]
Nothing special and I didn’t even code this but:

                           if(cmd.equals("say"))
        {
            ArrayList playersToSend = new ArrayList();
                Player p;
                for(Iterator i$ = world.getPlayers().iterator(); i$.hasNext(); playersToSend.add(p))
                    p = (Player)i$.next();
            String newStr = "@gre@";
            for(int i = 0; i < args.length; i++)
                newStr = (new StringBuilder()).append(newStr).append(args[i]).append(" ").toString();
            newStr = (new StringBuilder()).append("#adm#").append(player.getUsername()).append(": ").append(newStr).toString();
            Player pl;
            for(Iterator i$ = playersToSend.iterator(); i$.hasNext(); pl.getActionSender().sendMessage(newStr))
                pl = (Player)i$.next();
}

n.b. indenting is horrible blah blah…
[/quote]
Learn to program. claiming it’s belongs to someone else is lousy. A good programmer would recognise how horrible that code is.

        if (cmd.equals("say")) {
            StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(100);
            sb.append(player.getUsername()).append(" says: ");
            for (String s : args) {
                sb.append(s).append(" ");
            }

            String message = sb.toString(); //call toString here, so toString is only called ONCE
            message = message.substring(0, message.length() - 1);
            for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
                p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
            }
            return;
        }

That code should suffice. It’ll send the message to all players online (I presume that’s the effect you were after).[/quote]
String.concat() > StringBuilder’s face.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source

item.title: Anyone have a basic ::say command for rscd source
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“KO9, post:2, topic:224327”]Nothing special and I didn’t even code this but:

                           if(cmd.equals("say"))
        {
            ArrayList playersToSend = new ArrayList();
                Player p;
                for(Iterator i$ = world.getPlayers().iterator(); i$.hasNext(); playersToSend.add(p))
                    p = (Player)i$.next();
            String newStr = "@gre@";
            for(int i = 0; i < args.length; i++)
                newStr = (new StringBuilder()).append(newStr).append(args[i]).append(" ").toString();
            newStr = (new StringBuilder()).append("#adm#").append(player.getUsername()).append(": ").append(newStr).toString();
            Player pl;
            for(Iterator i$ = playersToSend.iterator(); i$.hasNext(); pl.getActionSender().sendMessage(newStr))
                pl = (Player)i$.next();
}

n.b. indenting is horrible blah blah…[/quote]
Learn to program. Claiming it belongs to someone else is lousy. A good programmer would recognise how horrible that code is.

        if (cmd.equals("say")) {
            StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(100);
            sb.append(player.getUsername()).append(" says: ");
            for (String s : args) {
                sb.append(s).append(" ");
            }

            String message = sb.toString(); //call toString here, so toString is only called ONCE
            message = message.substring(0, message.length() - 1);
            for (Player p : world.getPlayers()) {
                p.getActionSender().sendMessage(message);
            }
            return;
        }

That code should suffice. It’ll send the message to all players online (I presume that’s the effect you were after).

EDIT: Fixed a typo (or two).

Read full topic
